Ryanair splits opinion in City despite busiest December since pandemic
Ryanair splits opinion in City despite busiest December since pandemic
 
Proactive Investors (UK)
January 4, 2023 Wednesday 12:10 PM EST
Copyright 2023 Proactive UK Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 296 words
Byline: Leo Grieco
Body
Analysts remain cautious over Ryanair Holdings PLC (LSE:RYA) as passenger stats for December fell slightly short 
of market expectations despite reaching levels last seen prior to the Covid-19 pandemic.
Traffic numbers were some 2.6% higher than December 2019, at 11.2mln passengers, spanning some 65,500 
flights. Year-on-year comparison makes more impressive reading, as the monthly number comes in 21% above last 
December which was impacted by the Omicron variant of Covid.
Nevertheless, compiled with October and November volumes it leaves the low-cost airline short of analyst 
expectations for the final calendar quarter of 2022, and, looking into the airline's fourth fiscal quarter it now has 
some catching up to do if it is to reach its own targets for the year.
"The passenger figures for the quarter were slightly light of our forecast at 38.4mln (vs. our 40.5mln estimate), 
although that could imply a stronger fourth than we had assumed to reach management's 168mln target for the year 
to March 2023," Liberum Capital analyst Gerald Khoo said in a note.
"We retain a cautious stance with current consensus implying a double-digit percentage average fare improvement 
next FY, which strikes us as challenging in a likely recessionary environment.
Peel Hunt analyst Alexander Paterson, meanwhile, said: "This [target] should be achievable as long as there are no 
travel restrictions or sustained periods of bad weather."
At (EURO)12.475, Ryanair shares are down by slightly in Wednesday morning's dealing, and, remain off some 4% 
since early December.
Ryanair splits opinion in City despite busiest December since pandemic
Liberum retains a 'hold' rating for the airline's shares with its target price set at (EURO)13, whilst Peel Hunt by 
comparison is more bullish with its target pitched at (EURO)18 per share and its recommendation set as 'buy'.
Load-Date: January 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair 's passenger numbers lighter than expected and imply caution for sector
Ryanair's passenger numbers lighter than expected and imply caution for 
sector
 
Proactive Investors (UK)
January 4, 2023 Wednesday 09:20 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Proactive UK Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 220 words
Byline: Josh Lamb
Body
A rise in passenger figures from Ryanair Holdings PLC (LSE:RYA) for December were actually lower than expected 
and imply the need for a "cautious stance" on the airline's shares, according to analysts.
The low-cost airline flew some 11.5mln passengers in December, a 21% increase on the 9.5mln carried in the last 
month of 2021.
November saw passenger numbers increase by 10%, according to an update released today.
But rather than an impressive resurgence, analysts at Liberum suggested the figures were lighter than expected, 
reflecting a comparatively weaker month a year earlier.
READ: Hope springs again for British Airways, easyJet, Ryanair as passengers return
The figures from the same month in 2021 were impacted by the emergence of the Omicron variant of COVID and a 
resurgence in international travel restrictions, said Liberum, adding that Ryanair's third quarter figures of 38.4mln 
were below forecasts.
The broker had anticipated 40.5mln passengers would travel with the airline during the quarter but suggested "that 
could imply a stronger fourth quarter than we had assumed" given Ryanair's traffic guidance of 168mln passengers 
for the full year.
Ryanair 's passenger numbers lighter than expected and imply caution for sector
Liberum added: "We retain a cautious stance," with Ryanair's target of a double-digit percentage fare 
improvement "challenging in a likely recessionary environment".
Load-Date: January 4, 2023
End of Document
TOP NEWS: Ryanair raises full-year outlook after strong quarter
TOP NEWS: Ryanair raises full-year outlook after strong quarter
Alliance News UK
January 4, 2023 Wednesday 9:57 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Top News
Length: 251 words
Body
(Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC late on Wednesday raised its full-year profit guidance on a strong 
performance over the Christmas and New Year's Eve period.
The Dublin-based low-cost airline said that it expects a stronger-than-expected third-quarter performance, due to 
strong pent-up travel demand over the holiday season. 
The company noted that no damage from Covid or the war in Ukraine lead to strong Christmas and New Year traffic 
and fares. Ryanair's third quarter ends on December 31.
The firm now expects full-year post-tax profit in the range of EUR1.33 billion to EUR1.43 billion, up from an initial 
forecast of 1 billion to 1.2 billion euros.
For the third quarter that ended on December 31, it expects to report post-tax profit of as close to EUR200 million. 
However, the budget airline noted in a statement that the reassessment was "heavily dependent" on avoiding 
further fallout from "adverse events" such as Covid or the ongoing war in Ukraine.
Earlier on Wednesday, Ryanair said its December traffic rose 21% to 11.5 million guests from 9.5 million in 
December 2021.
The load factor improved to 92% from 81% a year earlier.
On a rolling 12-month basis, passenger numbers more than doubled to 160.4 million guests from a year ago and 
load factor the load factor rose to 92%, from 81%. 
It will publish its third-quarter results on January 30.
By Abby Amoakuh, Alliance News reporter
TOP NEWS: Ryanair raises full-year outlook after strong quarter
Comments and questions to newsroom@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2023 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: January 4, 2023
End of Document
TOP NEWS: Ryanair achieves higher passenger numbers in December
TOP NEWS: Ryanair achieves higher passenger numbers in December
Alliance News UK
January 4, 2023 Wednesday 08:13 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Top News; Company Significant; Company Positive
Length: 223 words
Body
(Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC on Wednesday reported it carried more passengers in December 
compared to a year earlier.
The Dublin-based low-cost airline said its December traffic rose 21% to 11.5 million guests from 9.5 million in 
December 2021. 
The load factor improved to 92% from 81% a year earlier. 
On a rolling 12-month basis, passenger numbers more than doubled to 160.4 million guests from a year ago and 
load factor the load factor rose to 92%, from 81%. 
The announcement came days after Ryanair cabin crews launched a three-day strike over the New Year holiday, 
grounding dozens of flights and hitting thousands of passengers. 
The industrial action came as the cost of living crisis spurs growing labour strife across Europe that has disrupted 
the festive period.
Charleroi airport Chief Executive Philippe Verdonck told AFP that the strike action would set to halt 30% of the 
airlines' flights through its Belgium hub. 
Overall, some 22,000 passengers were expected to be affected over the three days, he said. 
In early December, Ryanair said it carried 11.2 million passengers in November 2022, up 9.8% from 10.2 million a 
year earlier, and up 2.8% from 10.9 million in November 2019.
By Xindi Wei, Alliance News reporter
Comments and questions to newsroom@alliancenews.com
TOP NEWS: Ryanair achieves higher passenger numbers in December
Copyright 2022 Alliance News Ltd. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: January 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair 's Passenger Traffic Jumps 21% In December 2022
Ryanair's Passenger Traffic Jumps 21% In December 2022
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
January 4, 2023 Wednesday 2:10 AM EST
Copyright 2023 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 72 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYA.IR) said Wednesday that it flew a total of 11.5 million passengers in December 2022, 
reflecting a 21% year-over-year increase.
The Irish low-cost carrier's load factor for the final month of 2022 climbed to 92% from 81% in the previous year.
For the entire 12-month period, the airline's passenger traffic soared 121% to 160.4 million guests, with a load 
factor of 92%.
Ryanair gained nearly 3% on Tuesday's close.

Ryanair Lifts FY23 Profit Outlook After Strong Demand In Holiday Season
Ryanair Lifts FY23 Profit Outlook After Strong Demand In Holiday Season
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
January 4, 2023 Wednesday 10:47 PM EST
Copyright 2023 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 123 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYA.IR) upgraded its outlook for fiscal 2023, citing its stronger-than-anticipated third-quarter performance 
due to solid passenger traffic and fares during the first holiday season with no disruptions from COVID-19 or the 
Ukraine war.
The Irish low-cost air carrier now expects a full-year profit of between 1.33 billion euros to 1.43 billion euros, up 
from the prior 1 billion euros to 1.20 billion euros range, according to a Wednesday release. The company noted 
that the new outlook continues to be "heavily dependent" on various factors, including the pandemic or the Ukraine 
situation.
On the other hand, the airline maintained its traffic estimate of 168 million for fiscal 2023.
Ryanair gained over 2% on Wednesday's close.
Load-Date: January 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair expects higher annual profits after strong third quarter
Ryanair expects higher annual profits after strong third quarter
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 4, 2023 Wednesday 10:53 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 122 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Europe's largest low-cost airline Ryanair is expecting a higher annual profit than expected after a surprisingly strong 
third quarter.
After taxes and adjusted for special items, the company announced on Wednesday that it expects to post a profit of 
(EURO)1.325 to 1.425 billion ($1.5 billion) if no negative events follow.
Previously, Ryanair had assumed a figure of (EURO)1 to 1.2 billion.
The company still expects 168 million passengers for the financial year ending on 30 March.
A profit of just under (EURO)200 million is likely to have been achieved in the third quarter, the Irish firm added. A 
strong pent-up demand from customers was noted in the holiday season as the majority of coronavirus restrictions 
in Europe were abolished.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Mark Meadows; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: January 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Stock Holdings Decreased by Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Stock Holdings Decreased by 
Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC
Newstex Blogs 
Watchlist News
January 3, 2023 Tuesday 12:30 PM EST
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 928 words
Body
Jan 03, 2023( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  
 Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC decreased its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1] - 
Get Rating[2]) by 0.8% during the 3rd quarter, according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the SEC. The fund 
owned 127,672 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 1,000 shares during the period. 
Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC's holdings in Ryanair were worth $7,459,000 as of its most recent filing with the 
SEC.  
A number of other hedge funds have also bought and sold shares of the company. LPL Financial LLC raised its 
stake in Ryanair by 2.5% during the second quarter. LPL Financial LLC now owns 6,344 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $427,000 after buying an additional 153 shares in the last quarter. Harbor 
Investment Advisory LLC increased its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 8.4% in the 2nd quarter. Harbor Investment 
Advisory LLC now owns 2,471 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $166,000 after acquiring an 
additional 192 shares during the last quarter. Raymond James Trust N.A. raised its position in shares of Ryanair by 
5.8% during the 2nd quarter. Raymond James Trust N.A. now owns 3,602 shares of the transportation company's 
stock valued at $242,000 after acquiring an additional 196 shares in the last quarter. Ninety One UK Ltd raised its 
position in shares of Ryanair by 0.6% during the 1st quarter. Ninety One UK Ltd now owns 31,408 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $2,736,000 after acquiring an additional 198 shares in the last quarter. 
Finally, SVB Wealth LLC lifted its stake in Ryanair by 7.8% during the first quarter. SVB Wealth LLC now owns 
2,805 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $245,000 after purchasing an additional 202 shares 
during the last quarter. 42.82% of the stock is currently owned by institutional investors and hedge funds.  
Analyst Upgrades and Downgrades 
Several analysts have weighed in on the stock. JPMorgan Chase & Co. boosted their target price on shares of 
Ryanair from €18.20 ($19.36) to €21.00 ($22.34) and gave the company an 'overweight' rating in a research note 
on Thursday, December 15th. TheStreet raised shares of Ryanair from a 'c' rating to a 'b-' rating in a research 
report on Tuesday, December 20th. Liberum Capital cut shares of Ryanair from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a 
report on Wednesday, October 12th. Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft upped their target price on Ryanair from 
€14.50 ($15.43) to €16.00 ($17.02) and gave the company a 'buy' rating in a report on Tuesday, December 13th. 
Finally, Stifel Nicolaus downgraded Ryanair from a 'hold' rating to a 'sell' rating in a report on Wednesday, 
September 14th. One analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, two have assigned a hold rating, six have 
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Stock Holdings Decreased by Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC
assigned a buy rating and one has issued a strong buy rating to the company. According to data from 
MarketBeat.com, Ryanair currently has a consensus rating of 'Moderate Buy' and a consensus target price of 
$43.79. 
Ryanair Stock Performance 
 Shares of RYAAY[3] opened at $74.76 on Tuesday. The firm has a market capitalization of $17.03 billion, a PE 
ratio of 15.94 and a beta of 1.43. The company has a quick ratio of 1.08, a current ratio of 1.08 and a debt-to-equity 
ratio of 0.46. The firm has a 50-day moving average price of $74.52 and a 200 day moving average price of $70.88. 
Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52-week low of $55.90 and a 52-week high of $125.75.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1] - Get Rating[2]) last posted its quarterly earnings data on Monday, November 7th. 
The transportation company reported $5.32 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, missing the consensus 
estimate of $5.43 by ($0.11). Ryanair had a net margin of 10.85% and a return on equity of 16.66%. The company 
had revenue of $4.05 billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $4.02 billion. On average, 
sell-side analysts anticipate that Ryanair Holdings plc will post 5.45 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
About Ryanair 
 (Get Rating[2]) 
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-
free, and merchandise; and marketing of car hire and accommodation services, and travel insurance through its 
website and mobile app.

Ryanair Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC trimmed its position in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Rating ) by 0.8% during the third quarter, according to the company in its most recent 
Form 13F filing with the SEC. The institutional investor  owned 127,672 shares of the transportation company's 
stock after selling 1,000 shares during the quarter. Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC owned approximately 0.06% 
of Ryanair worth $7,459,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period.  
Several other large investors also recently bought and sold shares of RYAAY. Harding Loevner LP purchased a 
new position in shares of  Ryanair during the 1st quarter worth approximately $48,000.  Parallel Advisors LLC 
purchased a new position in  Ryanair during the second quarter worth $64,000.  Ronald Blue Trust Inc. acquired a 
new position in shares of  Ryanair in the second quarter worth $90,000.  Whittier Trust Co. of Nevada Inc. lifted its 
position in shares of  Ryanair by 656.4% in the third quarter. Whittier Trust Co. of Nevada Inc. now owns 1,770 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $103,000 after acquiring an additional 1,536 shares in the 
last quarter.  Finally, Zions Bancorporation N.A. boosted its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 26.0% during the first 
quarter. Zions Bancorporation N.A. now owns 1,900 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$166,000 after acquiring an additional 392 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors and hedge funds 
own  42.82% of the company's stock.  Ryanair Price Performance

and its 200 day moving average price is $70.88. Ryanair Holdings plc has a twelve month low of $55.90 and a 
twelve month high of $125.75. The company has a current ratio of 1.08, a quick ratio of 1.08 and a debt-to-equity 
ratio of 0.46. The stock has a market capitalization of $17.03 billion, a P/E ratio of 15.94 and a beta of 1.43.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Rating ) last released its quarterly earnings data on Monday, November 7th. The 
transportation company reported $5.32 earnings per share for the quarter, missing the consensus estimate of $5.43 
by ($0.11). Ryanair had a net margin of 10.85% and a return on equity of 16.66%. The firm had revenue of $4.05 
billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $4.02 billion.  As a group, research analysts anticipate 
that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post 5.45 earnings per share for the current year.  Wall Street Analyst Weigh In

to a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, November 15th. TheStreet upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "c" 
rating to a "b-" rating in a research report on Tuesday, December 20th. JPMorgan Chase & Co. lifted their target 
price on shares of Ryanair from  18.20 ($19.36) to  21.00 ($22.34) and gave the stock an "overweight" rating in a 
research note on Thursday, December 15th. Raymond James reduced their price target on Ryanair from $112.00 to

$102.00 and set a "strong-buy" rating on the stock in a research note on Wednesday, October 5th. Finally, Liberum 
Capital downgraded Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Wednesday, October 
12th. One investment analyst  has rated the stock with a sell rating, two have issued  a hold rating, six have issued

free, and merchandise; and marketing of car hire and accommodation services, and travel insurance through its 
website and mobile app.Featured Stories

Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC Trims Stake in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY )
Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC Trims Stake in Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
January 3, 2023 Tuesday
Copyright 2023 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 847 words
Body
Ryanair Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC lessened its position in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Rating ) by 0.8% during the third quarter, according to its most recent filing with the 
Securities & Exchange Commission. The fund owned 127,672 shares of the transportation company's stock after 
selling 1,000 shares during the quarter. Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC owned about 0.06% of Ryanair worth 
$7,459,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.  
Several other institutional investors also recently added to or reduced their stakes in the company. LPL Financial 
LLC increased its stake in  Ryanair by 2.5% in the second quarter. LPL Financial LLC now owns 6,344 shares of 
the transportation company's stock valued at $427,000 after purchasing an additional 153 shares during the period.  
Harbor Investment Advisory LLC increased its position in  Ryanair by 8.4% in the 2nd quarter. Harbor Investment 
Advisory LLC now owns 2,471 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $166,000 after acquiring an 
additional 192 shares during the period.  Raymond James Trust N.A. raised its stake in  Ryanair by 5.8% during the 
2nd quarter. Raymond James Trust N.A. now owns 3,602 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$242,000 after acquiring an additional 196 shares during the last quarter.  Ninety One UK Ltd lifted its position in  
Ryanair by 0.6% during the 1st quarter. Ninety One UK Ltd now owns 31,408 shares of the transportation 
company's stock worth $2,736,000 after acquiring an additional 198 shares during the period.  Finally, SVB Wealth 
LLC grew its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 7.8% in the 1st quarter. SVB Wealth LLC now owns 2,805 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $245,000 after purchasing an additional 202 shares during the last 
quarter. Institutional investors and hedge funds own  42.82% of the company's stock.  Analyst Upgrades and 
Downgrades
Several research firms have recently commented on RYAAY. Liberum Capital cut Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a 
"hold" rating in a research note on Wednesday, October 12th. JPMorgan Chase & Co. lifted their target price on 
shares of Ryanair from  18.20 ($19.36) to  21.00 ($22.34) and gave the company an "overweight" rating in a report 
on Thursday, December 15th. Stifel Nicolaus cut shares of Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "sell" rating in a report 
on Wednesday, September 14th. Raymond James lowered their price objective on Ryanair from $112.00 to 
$102.00 and set a "strong-buy" rating on the stock in a report on Wednesday, October 5th. Finally, StockNews.com  
raised Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, November 15th. One equities 
research analyst  has rated the stock with a sell rating, two have given a hold rating, six have assigned  a buy rating 
and one  has given a strong buy rating to the stock. Based on data from MarketBeat, the stock  has a consensus 
rating of "Moderate Buy" and a consensus target price of $43.79. Ryanair Price Performance
Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC Trims Stake in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY )

$74.52 and its 200-day simple moving average is $70.88. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.46, a current 
ratio of 1.08 and a quick ratio of 1.08. The firm has a market capitalization of $17.03 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio 
of 15.94 and a beta of 1.43. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12 month low of $55.90 and a 12 month high of $125.75.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Rating ) last released its quarterly earnings results on Monday, November 7th. 
The transportation company reported $5.32 EPS for the quarter, missing the consensus estimate of $5.43 by 
($0.11). Ryanair had a net margin of 10.85% and a return on equity of 16.66%. The business had revenue of $4.05 
billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $4.02 billion.  As a group, equities analysts forecast that

United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-

Air travel Europe recovers but punctuality suffers
Air travel Europe recovers but punctuality suffers
Newstex Blogs 
AirInsight
January 2, 2023 Monday 8:05 PM EST
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 957 words
Byline: Richard Schuurman
Body
Jan 02, 2023( AirInsight: http://airinsight.com Delivered by Newstex)  
 Air travel in Europe recovered to 83 percent of 2019 levels by the end of last year or to 9.3 million flights. This is 
3.1 million flights up on 2021, but still 1.9 million down on 2019, Eurocontrol says in its 2022 analysis paper[1]. The 
organization sees further recovery in 2023, but that won't come without issues. Air travel Europe recovers but 
punctuality suffers. 
Eurocontrol[2] notes that the recovery of the number of flights from 70 percent at the beginning of 2022 to on 
average 83 percent at the end is in some way remarkable, given that the first months were dominated by the 
downturn caused by the Omicron virus. And then, at the end of February, Russia started the war in Ukraine, which 
affected airspace in some parts of Europe. But the effects of both crises were rather limited and traffic already hit 86 
percent in May and remained between 86-88 percent for the rest of the year. 
https://i0.wp.com/airinsight.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/2023-01-02.png?ssl=1 
European airlines carried a combined two billion passengers last year. The busiest carrier by the umber of daily 
departures and arrivals was, as in 2019, Ryanair, with 2.536 daily flights. This is up nine percent on 2019 or 77.000 
flights over the full year. easyJet was runner-up with 1.335 flights, but this is twenty percent down on 2019. Turkish 
Airlines came third with 1.245 flights (-7 percent) and outpaced Lufthansa, which operated 158.000 fewer flights 
largely due to strikes last summer. Air France is in the fifth spot, ahead of KLM, whereas British Airways dropped 
two places in the listing, behind Wizz Air ahead of subsidiary Vueling and SAS. Wizz saw a fourteen percent 
increase in the number of flights, or 30.000 extra. 
'Lufthansa, Air France, and KLM, as traditional mainline carriers reliant on a hub model, have recovered slower than 
their low-cost counterparts. In particular, Lufthansa (-29 percent versus 2019) has seen a very weak recovery in 
German internal demand, with a rise in alternative methods of travel or reduced business travel by air', the 
Eurocontrol report notes. 
https://i0.wp.com/airinsight.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/2023-01-02-2.png?ssl=1 
Delays 
But as the year progressed, the more serious became staffing issues at airports and air navigation services 
providers across Europe. Flights departed on average 17.6 minutes late by the end of the year, up from 13.1 
minutes in 2019. 'Arrival schedule delay (actual arrival time compared with scheduled arrival time) increased to 16.9 
Air travel Europe recovers but punctuality suffers
min/flight from 12.7 min/flight in 2019 (+33 percent). Departure schedule delay was also up to 19.6 min/flight in 
2022, rising from 15.3 min/flight in 2019.' 
As a result, punctuality suffered: arrival punctuality was on average 71.7 percent, down 6.4 percent from 2019. 
Departure punctuality dripped by even 6.8 percent to 65.9 percent. During the summer peak, punctuality dropped to 
between 50-60 percent. Of the delay, on average 2.17 minutes was caused by air traffic management issues 
andATM inefficiencies.[3] 
In the top ten of most punctual European airlines, Vueling is in the top spot, followed by SAS (despite or maybe 
even thanks to the long summer strike), KLM, and Ryanair, while Wizz Air is in the top ten position with punctuality 
between 50 and 60 percent. 
https://i0.wp.com/airinsight.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/2023-01-02-4.png?ssl=1 
The busiest airport in Europe was Istanbul, which saw 1.156 daily flights. Despite the capacity cap that has been in 
place since June, Amsterdam Schiphol is closely behind with on average of 1.140 daily flights, which is just 
eighteen flights more than Paris Charles de Gaulle. 
Eurocontrol also looked at the status of carbon dioxide emissions. Between January and November 2022, these 
were 19.6 percent lower compared to 2019 at 15.1 percent fewer departures. Excess fuel burn was between 3.1 
and 6.1 percent, well below the seven to eight percent in 2019. The report notes that long-haul flights, which 
account for 5.5 percent of all flights, are responsible for 43.9 percent of all emissions. Short- to medium-haul flights 
(share 43 percent) cause 23.2 percent of emissions. 
https://i0.wp.com/airinsight.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/2023-01-02-3.png?ssl=1 
Outlook 
In its outlook for 2023, Eurocontrol expects air travel in Europe to further recover to 92 percent but not return to full 
pre-Covid levels until 2025. This is one year later than it the June forecast and takes the weak economic growth, 
inflation, and the continuation of the war in Ukraine into account. 
'However, 2023 is set to be the most challenging year of the last decade. Keeping summer delays down will be an 
immense task for all actors, with airspace issues due to the Ukraine war, new aircraft delivered, possible industrial 
action, system changes and the progressive reopening of Asian markets all asking real questions of the system.' 
 https://airinsight.com/author/schuurman/  
 Active as a journalist since 1987, with a background in newspapers, magazines, and a regional news station, 
Richard has been covering commercial aviation on a freelance basis since late 2016. In 2022, he has gone full-time 
freelance. Richard has been contributing to AirInsight since December 2018. He is also writing for Airliner World 
and Aviation News. From January 2023, he will add a part-time role with Dutch website and magazine 
Luchtvaartnieuws. Twitter: @rschuur_aero. 
 [ 1]: https://www.eurocontrol .int/publication/eurocontrol-analysis-paper-2022-year-european-aviation-bounced-
back [ 2]: http://www.eurocontrol.int [ 3]: https://airinsight.com/airlines-4-europe-liberalization-can-optimize-air-
traffic-management/ 
Link to the original story.
Notes

about the accuracy, completeness, or adequacy of the information contained therein or linked to from such content, 
Air travel Europe recovers but punctuality suffers
nor do they take responsibility for any aspect of such content. The Newstex Authoritative Content shall be 
construed as author-based content and commentary. Accordingly, no warranties or other guarantees are offered as 
to the quality of the opinions, commentary or anything else appearing in such Newstex Authoritative Content.

Supply squeeze extends to used aircraft
Supply squeeze extends to used aircraft
AirFinance Journal
January 2023
Copyright 2023 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 562 words
Byline: Laura Mueller
Body
Airlines and lessors are facing supply chain delays for used aircraft as demand soars from airlines responding to a 
rebound in bookings, according to a panel at Airfinance Journal's Dublin 2023 event. 
"The placement market for used equipment is not immune to supply chain issues," says Steven Udvar-Hazy, senior 
vice president and chief procurement officer of Aviation Capital Group.
"We've experienced challenges, especially as we've transitioned an airplane out of an operator, and when we 
needed to make some interior modifications for the next operator. You can hit bottlenecks in getting components, 
MRO slots and even engineering work can be challenging in this environment.
"These bottlenecks in the supply chain are holding up our ability to transition the airplane as efficiently and quickly 
as we like," he says.
The increase in demand for used aircraft means airlines can no longer rely on their supply to meet evolving flight 
schedules.
"As an airline, we try to enter opportunistic deals available on the market, and used aircraft used to be the platform 
that was relatively easily available. That's no longer the case," says Maciej Dziudzik, director of fleet LOT Polish 
Airlines.
Steve Mason, former head of OEM relations at Avolon, stresses the importance of aircraft supply for airlines in a 
post-pandemic operating environment.
"European airlines are in a really competitive environment. If you think of some of these airlines, such as Ryanair, if 
you don't have your aircraft, they will come and eat your lunch. You have to get seats and protect your markets.
"Airlines are in a fight. They will lose market share and that will ultimately have a long-term effect on their business."
Flybe, which collapsed into administration for the second time in two years, previously blamed an aircraft shortage 
for a series of disruptions over the summer months. 
Supply squeeze extends to used aircraft
In July, the airline's chief executive, Dave Pflieger, noted that two leasing companies were responsible flight 
cancellations. The move, he said in a statement, would affect schedules from 28 July until the end of the summer 
season on 29 October.
He said at the time: "We were planning to increase flights...However the two aircraft leasing companies who were 
contracted to provide our additional airplanes have now told us that they will be unable to fulfil their commitments 
until after the summer."
He added: "We were able to find and rent aircraft from two separate airlines in Greece and Spain, but those planes 
are not enough, and the lack of additional aircraft needed for new flying means we need to adjust our future flight 
schedule.
"As a result, we are reducing our planned increase in flying for the period."
Avolon has also weighed in on supply chain constraints in a recent white paper, saying delays have become 
"endemic" and an aircraft shortage is emerging given the lost production of 2,400 aircraft (1,700 single-aisle, 700 
widebody) that had been planned but were not built due to the pandemic.
"As traffic flows rebound, the absence of new aircraft is increasing supply tension, supporting long-term residual 
values," Avolon said.
Airbus and Boeing plan to produce a combined 140 narrowbody and 24 widebody aircraft per month by 2025. 
However, Avolon believes the manufacturers will need to delay production increases for a year to focus on 
"delivering to schedule and quality versus aspiration".
Load-Date: February 20, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair may see $200m profit boost
Ryanair may see $200m profit boost
AirFinance Journal
January 2023
Copyright 2023 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 253 words
Byline: Hugh Davies
Body
Ryanair is guiding for a stronger than expected third quarter, to 31 December 2022, as a result of strong pent-up 
demand over the winter holiday season.
The European low-cost airline group is predicting profit after tax of (EURO)200 million ($212 million) for the three-
month period.
As a result, the company has raised its fiscal-year 2023 profit after tax guidance from a range of (EURO)1 billion to 
(EURO)1.2 billion to (EURO)1.325 billion to (EURO)1.425 billion, although this remains dependent upon avoiding 
adverse events, Ryanair said in a statement.
Ryanair still expects Q4 to be loss-making due to the absence of Easter from March, and a recent softening in 
pricing.
In November 2022, Ryanair said it aimed to repay (EURO)1.6 billion of maturing bonds while returning its balance 
sheet to a broadly zero net debt position over the next year.
In the same month the carrier reported total liquidity of (EURO)4.6 billion, including (EURO)1.7 billion of cash and 
cash equivalents, (EURO)2.8 billion of financial assets convertible to cash after three months, as well as (EURO)23 
million of restricted cash.
Net debt was reduced to (EURO)546 million at the end of September versus (EURO)1.5 billion at 31 March, despite 
(EURO)900 million of capital expenditure in the first six months of fiscal-year 2023.
Gross debt increased by (EURO)60 million to (EURO)5 billion, primarily due to the extension of operating lease 
terms on 24 Airbus A320 aircraft until 2028 at lower rentals, offset by debt repayments during the period.
Load-Date: January 23, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair posts $230m net profit
Ryanair posts $230m net profit
AirFinance Journal
January 2023
Copyright 2023 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 411 words
Byline: Hugh Davies
Body
Ryanair Group recorded a net profit of (EURO)211 million ($230 million) for the three months ended 31 December 
2022, swinging from a loss of (EURO)96 million in the prior-year period and up from the (EURO)88 million profit in 
the October-December period in 2019 on the back of strong demand and fares.
Revenue increased 57% year-on-year to (EURO)2.3 billion, outpacing a 36% rise in operating costs to (EURO)2.2 
billion.
Fuel costs rose 52% to (EURO)900 million, offset by the introduction of Boeing 737 Max 8200 aircraft improving fuel 
efficiency. Ex-fuel operating costs rose by 26%, marginally ahead of traffic with year-to-date unit costs at (EURO)30 
per passenger.  
The company achieved a nine-percentage point increase in load factor to 93% for the third quarter.
Ryanair is expecting a "reasonably strong" Easter and summer season in 2023 but expects the fourth quarter of 
fiscal-year 2023 to be loss making due to the absence of Easter from March.
"Absent any negative news flows around Covid or Ukraine, it is very reasonable that we will have a second summer 
of rising fares because we will have materially higher oil prices," said Ryanair Group chief executive officer Michael 
O'Leary on an earnings call.
"Where do I think yields will be this summer? I honestly don't know but they will be stronger, up mid-to-high single 
digits from where they were in summer 2022 but it is still too early to say," O'Leary continued.
He noted that the strength of the balance sheet differentiates it from other European competitors.
"We'll be very busy over the next 12 months repaying the (EURO)1.6 billion of maturing bonds this year but we will 
use cash resources to pay that down."
"We will not refinance those bonds. Were we to try to refinance them, even with our strong investment grade rating 
and balance sheet, we would be looking at financing costs of 4.5-5% in the current environment.
Ryanair posts $230m net profit
"We have the resources to pay down that debt and fund capex - many of our competitors have exited Covid doing a 
lot of sale and leasebacks. The cost of those operating leases will go up meaningfully this year as interest rates go 
up whereas we will be paying off debt and 98% of our fleet is unencumbered.
"That will be a significant differentiator on the unit cost side between us and everybody else," O'Leary concluded.
Net debt at 31 December 2022 was (EURO)1 billion, down from (EURO)1.5 billion as of 31 March 2021, while cash 
amounted to (EURO)4.1 billion at the end of the quarter.
Load-Date: February 20, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair to be opportunistic on future orders: O'Leary
Ryanair to be opportunistic on future orders: O'Leary
AirFinance Journal
January 2023
Copyright 2023 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 355 words
Byline: Hugh Davies
Body
On the back of Ryanair Group's strong third-quarter results, chief executive officer Michael O'Leary said the 
company would still consider future Boeing 737 Max 10 or even Airbus deals as it looks to widen its cost advantage 
versus its European competitors.
"It's entirely down to pricing and whether there is a material cost per seat advantage," O'Leary said during an 
earnings call.
"We would buy whichever aircraft has the cheaper cost per seat. I would always take a bigger aircraft as long as I'm 
getting a better price per seat."
He noted the company would be willing to look at the Max 10 when it gets certified and when Boeing is able to 
deliver it, and as long as it offers a reasonable discount on the additional 30 seats that come with the extended 
narrowbody.
"We're back talking to Boeing on new aircraft orders but not in any serious way and don't expect anything significant 
to occur for at least a few months.
"Would we look at an Airbus order? Yes, we would, but it again comes down to being opportunistic. Airbus has a 
much longer orderbook than Boeing and have capitalised on Boeing's 737 Max delays and Airbus is a beneficiary of 
trade wars between China and the US.
"The Boeing orderbook is much weaker... so Airbus is pricing up materially which is good for us since most of our 
competitors are Airbus operators and are paying much higher prices for aircraft than we are for our Boeing orders."
O'Leary said the vast majority of Ryanair's growth will come from its Boeing orderbook rather than temporary 
leases. The carrier is looking to take delivery of at least 45 new 197-seat 737 Max 8200s by this summer.
"We're not usually searching for second hand aircraft, given that the Boeing 737 Max aircraft are coming in at a 
more predictable rate right now," O'Leary continued.
"We're not out actively looking for additional leased aircraft. We are receiving offers though and if they are 
financially and opportunistically interesting we will follow up on them up.
Ryanair to be opportunistic on future orders: O'Leary
"At the moment we have more than 120 aircraft to deliver over the next three years and so most of the growth will 
come from these fuel-efficient aircraft."
Load-Date: February 20, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY ) Given Consensus Rating of 'Moderate Buy' by Analysts
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Given Consensus Rating of 
'Moderate Buy' by Analysts
Newstex Blogs 
Zolmax.com
January 1, 2023 Sunday 9:06 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 926 words
Body
Jan 01, 2023( Zolmax.com: http://www.zolmax.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  
 Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1] - Get Rating[2]) has earned a consensus rating of "Moderate Buy" from 
the twelve analysts that are covering the firm, MarketBeat.com[3] reports. One investment analyst has rated the 
stock with a sell rating, two have issued a hold rating, five have issued a buy rating and one has assigned a strong 
buy rating to the company. The average 12 month target price among analysts that have covered the stock in the 
last year is $43.79.  
A number of analysts have recently commented on the company. Liberum Capital lowered Ryanair from a "buy" 
rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Wednesday, October 12th. StockNews.com[2] raised Ryanair from a 
"hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, November 15th. Raymond James cut their price 
objective on Ryanair from $112.00 to $102.00 and set a "strong-buy" rating on the stock in a research note on 
Wednesday, October 5th. TheStreet raised Ryanair from a "c" rating to a "b-" rating in a research note on Tuesday, 
December 20th. Finally, Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft lifted their price objective on Ryanair from €14.50 
($15.43) to €16.00 ($17.02) and gave the stock a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, December 13th. 
Institutional Investors Weigh In On Ryanair Several institutional investors have recently bought and sold shares of 
RYAAY. Capital International Investors grew its holdings in Ryanair by 18.0% during the first quarter. Capital 
International Investors now owns 11,270,188 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $981,539,000 
after buying an additional 1,722,195 shares in the last quarter. Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA grew its 
holdings in Ryanair by 11.2% during the second quarter. Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA now owns 
10,007,784 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $673,025,000 after buying an additional 1,009,514 
shares in the last quarter. Sprucegrove Investment Management Ltd. grew its holdings in Ryanair by 49.7% during 
the third quarter. Sprucegrove Investment Management Ltd. now owns 2,578,834 shares of the transportation 
company's stock worth $150,655,000 after buying an additional 856,560 shares in the last quarter. Lazard Asset 
Management LLC grew its holdings in Ryanair by 11.8% during the first quarter. Lazard Asset Management LLC 
now owns 5,787,913 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $504,242,000 after buying an additional 
612,114 shares in the last quarter. Finally, Royal Bank of Canada boosted its position in Ryanair by 27.5% in the 
first quarter. Royal Bank of Canada now owns 2,038,087 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$177,557,000 after purchasing an additional 439,740 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors own 
42.82% of the company's stock. Ryanair Stock Performance Ryanair stock[4] opened at $74.76 on Tuesday. 
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY ) Given Consensus Rating of 'Moderate Buy' by Analysts
Ryanair has a 12-month low of $55.90 and a 12-month high of $125.75. The company has a quick ratio of 1.08, a 
current ratio of 1.08 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.46. The business's 50-day moving average price is $74.30 and 
its two-hundred day moving average price is $70.82. The stock has a market cap of $17.03 billion, a PE ratio of 
15.94 and a beta of 1.47.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1] - Get Rating[2]) last released its earnings results on Monday, November 7th. The 
transportation company reported $5.32 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, missing analysts' consensus 
estimates of $5.43 by ($0.11). Ryanair had a net margin of 10.85% and a return on equity of 16.66%. The business 
had revenue of $4.05 billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $4.02 billion. As a group, 
analysts expect that Ryanair will post 5.45 earnings per share for the current fiscal year. Ryanair Company Profile 
(Get Rating[2]) Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services 
in Ireland, the United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and other European countries. It is also involved in the 
provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of 
beverages, food, duty-free, and merchandise; and marketing of car hire and accommodation services, and travel 
insurance through its website and mobile app. Featured StoriesGet a free copy of the StockNews.com research

Ryanair to focus on cash for Max deliveries: AFJ Dublin 2023
Ryanair to focus on cash for Max deliveries: AFJ Dublin 2023
AirFinance Journal
January 2023
Copyright 2023 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 168 words
Byline: Hugh Davies
Body
Ryanair is looking to incorporate another 50 Boeing 737 Max 8200s for fiscal year 2024, Thomas Fowler's director 
of sustainability and finance has said on the sidelines of Airfinance Journal's Dublin 2023 conference.
The company expects capital expenditure of around (EURO)2 billion ($2.2 billion) for the period, with Fowler noting 
that the company will rely on strong liquidity that it maintained during the Covid-19 pandemic for Capex.
"Our cash position put us in good stead during the pandemic," Fowler says. "We'll mostly be using cash to finance 
deliveries."
"Our focus over the next year is the repayment of (EURO)1.6 billion of maturing bonds, including (EURO)850 
million maturing in March and another (EURO)750 million in August," Fowler adds.
The carrier reported total liquidity of (EURO)4.6 billion as of 30 September, including (EURO)1.7 billion of cash and 
cash equivalents, (EURO)2.8 billion of financial assets convertible to cash after three months, as well as (EURO)23 
million of restricted cash.
Load-Date: February 6, 2023
End of Document
World Cargo Airlines adds third 737-800BCF
World Cargo Airlines adds third 737-800BCF
AirFinance Journal
January 2023
Copyright 2023 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 127 words
Byline: Hugh Davies
Body
Malaysian-based World Cargo Airlines has incorporated a third Boeing 737-800 converted freighter.
The aircraft is currently in storage at Kuala Lumpur's Subang airport.
The 2005-vintage aircraft is managed by BBAM and was acquired by Incline Aviation from Ryanair in 2021, 
according to Airfinance Journal's Fleet Tracker.
World Cargo Airlines operates another two 737-800 Boeing converted freighters (BCF), both also managed by 
BBAM, as well as one 747-400C, according to Fleet Tracker.
Last August, Incline Aviation and BBAM supported the launch of dedicated Vietnamese cargo carrier IPP Air Cargo 
with one 2004-vintage 737-800 converted freighter also acquired from Ryanair.
Three additional 737-800 freighters for IPP Air Cargo are expected to be delivered over time.
Load-Date: February 13, 2023
End of Document
Hope springs again for British Airways , easyJet , Ryanair as passengers return
Hope springs again for British Airways, easyJet, Ryanair as passengers 
return
 
Proactive Investors (UK)
December 30, 2022 Friday 07:08 AM EST
Copyright 2022 Proactive UK Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 700 words
Byline: Philip Whiterow
Body
Airlines have been the perennial recovery stocks of the past three years.
Since the start of 2021 pundits have confidently been calling that this would be the year in which the carriers finally 
got over their Covid hangover and start growing again.
Alas, the reality has been a lot trickier and come the start of 2023 investors in airlines are still yet to see a return to 
anywhere near the share price levels of 2019.
Timing though is critical in investing hence airlines again are featuring heavily in many tips of the year lists.
A reason is that while share prices might be lagging behind pre-covid levels, at the operational level things are 
looking much brighter.
All of the listed airlines IAG (British Airways,) Ryanair, EasyJet, Jet2 and WizzAir have issued bullish updates in 
recent months driven by better passenger numbers and higher capacity levels but also pricing.
Ryanair is the European leader and posted a pre-tax profit of (EURO)1.4bn (£1.2bn) in the six months to the end of 
September following a net loss of (EURO)48m in the same period last year.
Michael O'Leary, chief executive, said "Concerns about the impact of recession and rising consumer price inflation 
on Ryanair's business model have been greatly exaggerated."
Hope springs again for British Airways , easyJet , Ryanair as passengers return
O'Leary added he expects the airline "to grow strongly in a recession as consumers won't stop flying, but rather 
they will become more price sensitive."
Ryanair flew 95mln passengers in its first half, up from 39mln a year earlier and 11% more than the 85.7mln in the 
same period in 2019 before Covid grounded almost all air travel.
While the Irish carrier is ahead of its rivals in getting passenger numbers back, the trend is consistent.
British Airways' owner IAG said fourth-quarter capacity is expected to be approximately 87% of 2019 with the first 
quarter of 2023 expected to be approximately 95% of pre-Covid levels.
"Leisure demand is particularly healthy and leisure revenue has recovered to pre-pandemic levels," noted chief 
executive Luis Gallego.
"Business travel continues to recover steadily," he added, though this was before the US "bomb cyclone".
All encouraging, especially with new more efficient planes on the way and fuel prices starting to turn down, but like 
Ryanair ((EURO)11.22), IAG's share price (129p) has refused to go anywhere this year.
Possibly it's due to caution after the previous false dawns but TUI gave a clue as to why it might still be a little early 
to back the sector.
In an update in December, the travel group said it expected a "solid and a good year in 2023" with prices for the 
winter season up 28%.
Sebastian Ebel, the group's new chief executive, even went as far as to say "We have surmounted the existential 
crisis [Covid], it's behind us."
Maybe, but some legacies remain and in almost the same statement TUI confirmed it was planning a rights issue in 
the New Year to raise between (EURO)1.6-1.8bn.
That will clear the bailouts received from the German government at the start of the pandemic.
And there's the rub. TUI is unlikely to be an exception and there is a nagging feeling that as soon as share prices 
allow other airlines won't be shy about raising funds.
IAG, for example, has net debt of around (EURO)11bn even though its boasts "strong liquidity" while easyJet's 
debts are £700mln.
Even Ryanair, seen as the strongest of the airline bunch, was carrying debt of (EURO)500mln at its last showing.
Perhaps the best bet for the sector, therefore, is consolidation. WizzAir has already approached easyJet about a 
potential merger and possibly as a defensive measure.
EasyJet has also reportedly attracted the attention of IAG and at a conference earlier in the year Gallego hinted that 
the BA, Vueling and Iberia owner was mulling its expansion options.
"We are a platform for consolidation. We will only do what makes sense but we see there are opportunities to be 
stronger. We are a group that wants to consolidate the industry," he said.
Ryanair too is expected to be involved as a buyer if, or more likely when, any shake-out occurs.
So for those looking for an airline sector recovery story this year, the angle might be to overlook the strong and go 
for the least obvious as that's where the takeover action could be.
Load-Date: December 30, 2022
Hope springs again for British Airways , easyJet , Ryanair as passengers return
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Receives $43.79 Average PT from Analysts
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Receives $43.79 Average PT from 
Analysts
Newstex Blogs 
Watchlist News
December 30, 2022 Friday 7:35 AM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 786 words
Body
Dec 30, 2022( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  
 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1] - Get Rating[2]) have earned a consensus rating of 'Moderate 
Buy' from the twelve analysts that are covering the firm, Marketbeat Ratings[3] reports. One equities research 
analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, two have given a hold rating, five have assigned a buy rating and one 
has assigned a strong buy rating to the company. The average 1-year target price among analysts that have issued 
a report on the stock in the last year is $43.79.  
A number of research analysts have issued reports on RYAAY shares. StockNews.com[2] upgraded Ryanair from a 
'hold' rating to a 'buy' rating in a research report on Tuesday, November 15th. Liberum Capital cut shares of Ryanair 
from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a report on Wednesday, October 12th. TheStreet raised Ryanair from a 'c' 
rating to a 'b-' rating in a report on Tuesday, December 20th. Raymond James lowered their price target on Ryanair 
from $112.00 to $102.00 and set a 'strong-buy' rating on the stock in a research report on Wednesday, October 5th. 
Finally, Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft raised their target price on Ryanair from €14.50 ($15.43) to €16.00 
($17.02) and gave the company a 'buy' rating in a research note on Tuesday, December 13th. 
Ryanair Stock Up 2.3 % 
Shares of Ryanair stock[4] opened at $75.18 on Tuesday. Ryanair has a twelve month low of $55.90 and a twelve 
month high of $125.75. The stock has a market capitalization of $17.12 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 16.03 and 
a beta of 1.47. The company has a current ratio of 1.08, a quick ratio of 1.08 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.46. The 
business's 50 day simple moving average is $74.07 and its 200-day simple moving average is $70.78.  
 Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1] - Get Rating[2]) last released its quarterly earnings data on Monday, November 7th. 
The transportation company reported $5.32 earnings per share for the quarter, missing analysts' consensus 
estimates of $5.43 by ($0.11). Ryanair had a return on equity of 16.66% and a net margin of 10.85%. The firm had 
revenue of $4.05 billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $4.02 billion. Equities research 
analysts forecast that Ryanair will post 5.45 earnings per share for the current year. Institutional Inflows and 
Outflows 
Several hedge funds and other institutional investors have recently made changes to their positions in RYAAY. 
Signaturefd LLC boosted its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 399.0% during the third quarter. Signaturefd LLC now 
owns 514 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $30,000 after purchasing an additional 411 shares 
during the period. Rockefeller Capital Management L.P. boosted its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 34.2% during 
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Receives $43.79 Average PT from Analysts
the third quarter. Rockefeller Capital Management L.P. now owns 691 shares of the transportation company's stock 
worth $39,000 after purchasing an additional 176 shares during the period. Harding Loevner LP acquired a new 
stake in shares of Ryanair during the first quarter worth approximately $48,000. Parallel Advisors LLC acquired a 
new stake in shares of Ryanair during the second quarter worth approximately $64,000. Finally, Ronald Blue Trust 
Inc. acquired a new stake in shares of Ryanair during the second quarter worth approximately $90,000. 42.82% of 
the stock is currently owned by institutional investors and hedge funds.  
About Ryanair 
 (Get Rating[2]) 
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-
free, and merchandise; and marketing of car hire and accommodation services, and travel insurance through its 
website and mobile app.

Ryanair Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Rating ) has been assigned a consensus recommendation 
of "Moderate Buy" from the twelve ratings firms that are  covering the company, MarketBeat.com  reports. One 
research analyst  has rated the stock with a sell rating, two have assigned  a hold rating, five have given a buy 
rating and one  has issued  a strong buy rating on  the company. The average 1-year price objective among brokers 
that have issued a report on the stock in the last year is $43.79.  
Several equities research analysts have weighed in on RYAAY shares. TheStreet upgraded shares of Ryanair from 
a "c" rating to a "b-" rating in a research note on Tuesday, December 20th. Stifel Nicolaus downgraded shares of 
Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "sell" rating in a research note on Wednesday, September 14th. Liberum Capital 
downgraded shares of Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Wednesday, October 
12th. Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft lifted their price objective on shares of Ryanair from  14.50 ($15.43) to  
16.00 ($17.02) and gave the stock a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, December 13th. Finally, Raymond 
James lowered their price objective on shares of Ryanair from $112.00 to $102.00 and set a "strong-buy" rating for 
the company in a research note on Wednesday, October 5th. Ryanair Stock Performance

of 16.03 and a beta of 1.47. The firm's 50 day simple moving average is $74.07 and its 200-day simple moving 
average is $70.78. Ryanair has a one year low of $55.90 and a one year high of $125.75. The company has a debt-
to-equity ratio of 0.46, a quick ratio of 1.08 and a current ratio of 1.08.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Rating ) last issued its earnings results on Monday, November 7th. The 
transportation company reported $5.32 EPS for the quarter, missing analysts' consensus estimates of $5.43 by 
($0.11). The company had revenue of $4.05 billion for the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $4.02 
billion. Ryanair had a return on equity of 16.66% and a net margin of 10.85%.  As a group, equities analysts predict 
that  Ryanair will post 5.45 EPS for the current year.  Hedge Funds Weigh In On Ryanair
Institutional investors and hedge funds have recently bought and sold shares of the company. Signaturefd LLC 
lifted its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 399.0% in the 3rd quarter. Signaturefd LLC now owns 514 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $30,000 after acquiring an additional 411 shares during the last quarter.

an additional 176 shares in the last quarter.  Harding Loevner LP acquired a new stake in  Ryanair during the 1st

Ryanair three-day strike in Belgium grounds dozens of flights
Ryanair three-day strike in Belgium grounds dozens of flights
Alliance News UK
December 30, 2022 Friday 10:24 AM GMT
Copyright 2022 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Company Negative
Length: 269 words
Body
(Alliance News) - Belgian-based Ryanair Holdings PLC cabin crews on Friday launched a three-day strike over the 
New Year holiday, grounding dozens of flights and hitting thousands of passengers. 
The industrial action comes as the cost of living crisis spurs growing labour strife across Europe that has disrupted 
the festive period.
Charleroi airport CEO Philippe Verdonck told AFP 48 outgoing and incoming Ryanair flights had been cancelled on 
Friday, with the action set to halt 30% of the airlines' flights through its Belgium hub. 
Overall some 22,000 passengers were expected to be affected over the three days, he said. 
The low-cost Irish carrier has 15 planes in Belgium and the strike was not due to impact its aircraft based in other 
countries. 
Ryanair employees in Belgium have already gone on strike several times this year to demand that the country's 
labour laws be fully applied, grounding aircraft.
The unions notably accused Ryanair of illegally pressuring staff in Belgium to work from time to time in other sites 
across Europe, particularly in its home base Dublin, where the airline suffers employee shortages.
They also allege Ryanair, Europe's biggest airline in terms of passengers transported, is not properly declaring 
salaries to Belgian social security authorities and sometimes paying wages under the national legal minimum.
The unions are also planning to strike over the weekend of January 7 and 8 at the end of Belgium's traditional 
winter break.
Ryanair shares fell 0.7% to EUR12.10 each in Frankfurt on Friday afternoon.
Ryanair three-day strike in Belgium grounds dozens of flights
source: AFP
Copyright 2022 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.

End of Document
Ryanair Scraps 48 Flights In Belgium Amid Three-day Cabin Crew Strike
Ryanair Scraps 48 Flights In Belgium Amid Three-day Cabin Crew Strike
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
December 30, 2022 Friday 6:33 AM EST
Copyright 2022 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 108 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYA.IR) canceled 48 flights to and from Belgium on Friday as the local cabin crews commenced an 
industrial action set to last for three days, Agence France-Presse reported the same day.
Brussels South Charleroi Airport Boss Philippe Verdonck told AFP that roughly 30% of the Irish airline's flights in 
Belgium will be affected over the course of the strike. The industrial action is not expected to impact Ryanair's jets 
in other countries.
The unions, which have accused the low-cost carrier of paying below Belgium's legal minimum wage, plan to go on 
strike again on Jan. 7, 2023, and Jan. 8, 2023.
Ryanair lost more than 1% on Friday morning.
Load-Date: December 30, 2022
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY ) Receives $43.79 Consensus Price Target from Analysts
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Receives $43.79 Consensus Price 
Target from Analysts
Newstex Blogs 
Ticker Report
December 30, 2022 Friday 8:06 AM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 858 words
Body
Dec 30, 2022( Ticker Report: http://www.tickerreport.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  
 Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1] - Get Rating[2]) has been assigned a consensus recommendation of 
"Moderate Buy" from the twelve ratings firms that are covering the company, MarketBeat.com[3] reports. One 
research analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, two have assigned a hold rating, five have given a buy rating 
and one has issued a strong buy rating on the company. The average 1-year price objective among brokers that 
have issued a report on the stock in the last year is $43.79.  
Several equities research analysts have weighed in on RYAAY shares. TheStreet upgraded shares of Ryanair from 
a "c" rating to a "b-" rating in a research note on Tuesday, December 20th. Stifel Nicolaus downgraded shares of 
Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "sell" rating in a research note on Wednesday, September 14th. Liberum Capital 
downgraded shares of Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Wednesday, October 
12th. Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft lifted their price objective on shares of Ryanair from €14.50 ($15.43) to 
€16.00 ($17.02) and gave the stock a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, December 13th. Finally, 
Raymond James lowered their price objective on shares of Ryanair from $112.00 to $102.00 and set a "strong-buy" 
rating for the company in a research note on Wednesday, October 5th. Ryanair Stock Performance Shares of 
NASDAQ:RYAAY[4] opened at $75.18 on Tuesday. The firm has a market cap of $17.12 billion, a PE ratio of 16.03 
and a beta of 1.47. The firm's 50 day simple moving average is $74.07 and its 200-day simple moving average is 
$70.78. Ryanair has a one year low of $55.90 and a one year high of $125.75. The company has a debt-to-equity 
ratio of 0.46, a quick ratio of 1.08 and a current ratio of 1.08.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1] - Get Rating[2]) last issued its earnings results on Monday, November 7th. The 
transportation company reported $5.32 EPS for the quarter, missing analysts' consensus estimates of $5.43 by 
($0.11). The company had revenue of $4.05 billion for the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $4.02 
billion. Ryanair had a return on equity of 16.66% and a net margin of 10.85%. As a group, equities analysts predict 
that Ryanair will post 5.45 EPS for the current year. Hedge Funds Weigh In On Ryanair Institutional investors and 
hedge funds have recently bought and sold shares of the company. Signaturefd LLC lifted its holdings in shares of 
Ryanair by 399.0% in the 3rd quarter. Signaturefd LLC now owns 514 shares of the transportation company's stock 
worth $30,000 after acquiring an additional 411 shares during the last quarter. Rockefeller Capital Management 
L.P. lifted its holdings in Ryanair by 34.2% during the 3rd quarter. Rockefeller Capital Management L.P. now owns 
691 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $39,000 after buying an additional 176 shares in the last 
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY ) Receives $43.79 Consensus Price Target from Analysts
quarter. Harding Loevner LP acquired a new stake in Ryanair during the 1st quarter worth approximately $48,000. 
Parallel Advisors LLC acquired a new stake in Ryanair during the 2nd quarter worth approximately $64,000. Finally, 
Ronald Blue Trust Inc. acquired a new stake in Ryanair during the 2nd quarter worth approximately $90,000. 
42.82% of the stock is currently owned by institutional investors and hedge funds. Ryanair Company Profile (Get 
Rating[2]) Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in 
Ireland, the United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and other European countries. It is also involved in the 
provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of 
beverages, food, duty-free, and merchandise; and marketing of car hire and accommodation services, and travel

Domestic carriers operated a record 2,919 flights on Dec 29
Domestic carriers operated a record 2,919 flights on Dec 29
Newstex Blogs 
The Hindu Business Line
December 30, 2022 Friday 11:06 PM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 404 words
Body
Dec 30, 2022( The Hindu Business Line: http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  
 STATES Full recovery. 'India is top among 5 markets closest to achieving 2019 capacity' Indian carriers operated 
2,919 domestic flights, over 93.14 per cent of the approved schedule, on December 29, highest since the re-start 
post-Covid , according to Network Thoughts' analysis. 
According to the Ministry of Civil Aviation's (MoCA) data, over 4,15,314 passengers flew on 2,919 flights. The total 
flight movements were 5,833. 
Load factor 
Air India's flights were 90.5 per cent full. SpiceJet's were at 89.9 per cent, Vistara's at 88.8 per cent, Go First 86.7 
per cent and Air Asia India's was 85.9 percent. IndiGo's passenger load factor was 81.4 per cent and Akasa Air's at 
81.8 per cent. 
Cumulatively they carried 4,35,500 passengers post-Covid on December 24, 2022. This was the highest number of 
passengers travelled in a day post-Covid. 
Interestingly, Indian carriers are the second in line to add scheduled capacity back since 2019. According to 
aviation consultancy OAG's data, at the top twenty country markets, not surprisingly, the US leads the chart with 
just over 1 billion seats this year, a staggering 56 per cent up on 2021 capacity although still 7 per cent below the 
2019 high tide mark. 
Low-cost sector 
'There are in total five country markets that are within touching distance of their 2019 capacity, the closest is India 
at -5.7 per cent and the market certainly has room for further recovery with new aircraft orders being placed and a 
resurgent low-cost sector growing demand (although several operational challenges remain around aircraft spare 
parts and resources),' it said. 
In 2019, Indian airlines had 211,423,887 seats, which dipped to 127,490,029 in 2020. In 2021, airlines in India 
increased their total seat capacity to 153,419,332. This number has reached close to 199,474,691 in 2022, 
recording a 30 per cent year-on-year (y-o-y) rise and a 56 per cent rise since 2020. However, it is still lagging by 5.7 
per cent to reach the pre-Covid levels. 
According to OAG, IndiGo is among the three global airlines that are now operating at higher capacity than in 2019. 
Ryanair is at +12 per cent of pre-Covid, Indigo, too, is at +12 per cent and Spirit Airlines is at +17 per cent. On a y-
o-y basis, IndiGo added a capacity of 37.7 per cent and a 77 per cent rise since 2020. 
Link to the original story.
Domestic carriers operated a record 2,919 flights on Dec 29

Ryanair cabin crews strike in Belgium , dozens of flights grounded
Ryanair cabin crews strike in Belgium, dozens of flights grounded
Newstex Blogs 
Al Jazeera English
December 30, 2022 Friday 11:14 AM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 263 words
Body
Dec 30, 2022( Al Jazeera English: https://www.aljazeera.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  
 Belgium-based Ryanair cabin crews have started a three-day strike, resulting in dozens of the low-cost Irish 
carrier's flights being grounded and affecting thousands of passengers. 
The strike came on Friday as the cost of living crisis continued, increasing labour strife across Europe that has 
disrupted the festive period. 
Ryanair employees in Belgium have already gone on strike several times this year to demand that the country's 
labour laws be fully applied, grounding aircraft. 
The labour unions have notably accused Ryanair of illegally pressuring staff in Belgium to work from time to time in 
other sites across Europe, particularly in its home base Dublin, where the airline suffers employee shortages. 
They also allege Ryanair, Europe's biggest airline in terms of passengers transported, is not properly declaring 
salaries to Belgian social security authorities and is sometimes paying wages under the national legal minimum. 
Charleroi airport CEO Philippe Verdonck said 48 outgoing and incoming Ryanair flights had been cancelled on 
Friday, expecting the strike to halt 30 percent of the airlines' flights through its Belgium hub. 
Overall, about 22,000 passengers were expected to be affected over the three days, he added. 
Ryanair has 15 planes in Belgium and the strike was not due to affect its aircraft based in other countries. 
The unions are also planning to strike over the weekend of January 7 and 8 at the end of Belgium's traditional 
winter break.

Airline Stock Roundup: Massive Flight Cancellations at LUV , UAL in Focus
Airline Stock Roundup: Massive Flight Cancellations at LUV, UAL in Focus
Newstex Blogs 
Zacks Investment Research
December 29, 2022 Thursday 4:00 PM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1095 words
Byline: Maharathi Basu
Body
Dec 29, 2022( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  
 In the past week, Southwest Airlines LUV[1]was the chief newsmaker, albeit for wrong reasons. The Dallas-based 
carrier was the worst affected U.S. airline in terms of flight cancellations due to unfavorable weather conditions 
during the Christmas holiday weekend. Meanwhile, United Airlines UAL[2] management decided to resume 
operations to Tokyo from Denver. This route was suspended when the pandemic was wreaking havoc. Recap of 
the Latest Top Stories 1Southwest Airlines canceled 62% of its flights on Dec 27. What is worse is that LUV's rivals 
have seen their operations being disrupted at a much lower scale. We note that LUV is the biggest carrier serving 
Buffalo, NY, the hardest-hit urban area by this natural catastrophe. Management has apologized to passengers for 
the harassment they had to face due to the disruption in operations. The disruption is likely to hit LUV's fourth-
quarter 2022 performance. Many market watchers believe that it will take around a week for LUV to recover from 
this fiasco of gigantic proportions. 
LUV was also in the news recently when the union, International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, 
covering its customer service employees, ratified a pay-related deal. That story was covered in the previous week's 
write-up[3]. 
2. UAL will resume operating non-stop flights from Denver to Tokyo from Mar 4, 2023. Return flights from Tokyo's 
Narita International Airport to Denver International Airport will start taking to the skies from Mar 5, 2023. Initially, the 
service will be available three times a week. Flights will depart from Denver to Tokyo on Monday, Thursday and 
Saturday. Return flights to Denver will take to the skies on Tuesday, Friday and Sunday. Flights on the route will 
operate daily from Mar 25, 2023[4]. UAL currently sports a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). 
You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank stocks here[5] 
3. Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[6] along with the likes of Wizz Air and easyJet, will reportedly[7] face an inquiry by anti-
trust authorities in Italy over allegations of price-fixing. The allegations surfaced for flights operated by the airlines in 
and out of Sicily. The enquiry is expected to be completed by 2023-end.A complaint of price-fixing lodged by 
consumer group Codacons has led to the investigation. 
4. With COVID-19 cases on the rise in China, the United States has announced that passengers coming to the 
country from China, Hong Kong or Macau are required[8] to show negative COVID-19 test reports. The requirement 
will come into force from Jan 5, 2023 and is applicable to passengers above two years. Per the new rule announced 
by the Biden administration, passengers traveling to the United States directly from China and also those who were

in thecountry 10 days beforetheir departure to the United States will have to take a COVID-19 test (no more than 
two days before travel) and furnish a negative report before boarding the flight. Performance The following table

European Shares Muted, UK Outperforms As China-exposed Stocks Jump
European Shares Muted, UK Outperforms As China-exposed Stocks Jump
Newstex Blogs 
International Business Times News
December 28, 2022 Wednesday 10:45 AM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 487 words
Byline: Reuters
Body
Dec 28, 2022( International Business Times News: https://www.ibtimes.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  
 European shares were subdued on Wednesday, while UK's FTSE 100 outpaced peers after a long Christmas 
holiday weekend as investors assessed Beijing's steps towards reopening its COVID-battered economy. 
The region-wide STOXX 600 was flat as of 9:31 GMT, while the FTSE 100  <.FTSE > advanced 0.7% as 
commodity-linked and China-exposed stocks jumped in early trading. The UK market, which was closed for 
holidays since its half-day trading on Friday, is playing catch-up, analysts said. 
The FTSE 100 index has benefited this year from its exposure to commodities as prices of oil and base metals have 
rallied amid the Russia-Ukraine war. 
"The UK index could end the year in positive territory despite the broad pressures on global equity markets, 
weighed down by rising interest rates, inflation, and the threat of recession," said Victoria Scholar, head of 
investment at Interactive Investor. 
Miners jumped 1.0% as copper prices rallied on hopes of a demand recovery in the world's second-largest 
economy after China further eased its stringent COVID curbs on Monday. 
London-listed financials exposed to China such as insurer Prudential and HSBC added 2.6% and 1.3%, 
respectively.  
Meanwhile, STOXX 600 was headed for an annual loss of 12.2% as concerns about an economic recession due to 
aggressive monetary policy tightening by central banks globally weighed on the European index. 
The technology sector weighed on STOXX 600 on Wednesday, tracking the overnight fall in U.S. peers as rising 
yields pressured the interest rate sensitive shares, a recurring theme this year.  
Tech shares have fallen nearly 28.4% so far in 2022.  
Germany's Infineon fell 1.1% amid broader tech moves and after Chief Executive Jochen Hanebeck said it is ready 
to spend several billion euros on the right takeover target as it searches for acquisitions. 
Ireland's stock market  <.ISEQ >, which was also closed since its half-day trading on Friday, slipped 0.1%.  
Traders and analysts said thin trading volumes also influenced market moves. 
China-exposed luxury firms extended gains, with Kering and Richemont rising 0.2% and 0.8%, respectively.  
Italy's antitrust regulator said on Tuesday it had opened an inquiry into possible price-fixing for flights in and out of 
Sicily by airlines including Ryanair, Wizz Air and easyJet. Shares of the airlines fell between 1.2% and 2%. 
European Shares Muted, UK Outperforms As China-exposed Stocks Jump
"2022 was meant to be the year of the comeback for international travel with a major pick-up in demand post 
pandemic," added Scholar.  
"However there have been serious challenges with baggage handling, cancellations, the war in Ukraine, strikes and 
general disruption which have prompted these stocks to slide year-to-date, resulting in another difficult year for the 
airline industry." 
EasyJet denied any wrongdoing in a statement to Reuters. 
Link to the original story.

Authoritative Content") are solely those of the respective author(s) and not necessarily the views of Newstex or its 
re-distributors. Stories from such authors are provided "AS IS," with no warranties, and confer no rights. The
